The location of Germany. The countries in white are other members of the
[European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Deutschland_politisch_2010.png/250px-
Deutschland_politisch_2010.png)](/wiki/File:Deutschland_politisch_2010.png)

[](/wiki/File:Deutschland_politisch_2010.png "Enlarge")

General map of Germany

**Germany** is a country in [west](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western
Europe")-[central Europe](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe"), that
stretches from the [Alps](/wiki/Alps "Alps"), across the [North European
Plain](/wiki/North_European_Plain "North European Plain") to the [North
Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North Sea") and the [Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_Sea
"Baltic Sea"). [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany") has the second largest
population in Europe (after the [European](/wiki/Europe "Europe") part of
[Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia")) and is [seventh largest in
area](/wiki/Area_and_population_of_European_countries#Area "Area and
population of European countries"). The territory of Germany covers 357,021
km2 (137,847 sq mi), consisting of 349,223 km2 (134,836 sq mi) of land and
7,798 km2 (3,011 sq mi) of waters.

Elevation ranges from the mountains of the [Alps](/wiki/Alps "Alps") (highest
point: the [Zugspitze](/wiki/Zugspitze "Zugspitze") at 2,962 metres (9,718
ft)) in the south to the shores of the [North Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North
Sea") (Nordsee) in the northwest and the [Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic
Sea") (Ostsee) in the northeast. Between lie the forested uplands of central
Germany and the low-lying lands of northern Germany (lowest point: [Neuendorf-
Sachsenbande](/wiki/Neuendorf-Sachsenbande "Neuendorf-Sachsenbande") at 3.54
metres (11.6 ft) below sea level), traversed by some of Europe's major
[rivers](/wiki/River "River") such as the [Rhine](/wiki/Rhine "Rhine"),
[Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") and [Elbe](/wiki/Elbe "Elbe").[2]

Germany shares borders with nine European countries, second only to Russia:
[Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark") in the north, [Poland](/wiki/Poland
"Poland") and the [Czech Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic "Czech Republic") in
the east, [Switzerland](/wiki/Switzerland "Switzerland") (its only
non-[EU](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") neighbor) and
[Austria](/wiki/Austria "Austria") in the south, [France](/wiki/France
"France") in the southwest and [Belgium](/wiki/Belgium "Belgium"),
[Luxembourg](/wiki/Luxembourg "Luxembourg") and the
[Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands") in the west.

## Area[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_Germany&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Area")]

Germany is in [Western](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western Europe") and
[Central](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe") [Europe](/wiki/Europe
"Europe"), bordering [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark") in the north,
[Poland](/wiki/Poland "Poland") and the [Czech Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic
"Czech Republic") in the east, [Austria](/wiki/Austria "Austria") and
[Switzerland](/wiki/Switzerland "Switzerland") in the south,
[France](/wiki/France "France") and [Luxembourg](/wiki/Luxembourg
"Luxembourg") in the south-west, and [Belgium](/wiki/Belgium "Belgium") and
the [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands") in the north-west. It lies
mostly between latitudes [47°](/wiki/47th_parallel_north "47th parallel
north") and [55° N](/wiki/55th_parallel_north "55th parallel north") (the tip
of [Sylt](/wiki/Sylt "Sylt") is just north of 55°), and longitudes
[5°](/wiki/5th_meridian_east "5th meridian east") and [16°
E](/wiki/16th_meridian_east "16th meridian east"). The territory covers
357,021 km2 (137,847 sq mi), consisting of 349,223 km2 (134,836 sq mi) of land
and 7,798 km2 (3,011 sq mi) of water. It is the seventh largest country by
area in Europe and the 63rd largest in the world.[2]

### Maritime
claims[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_Germany&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Maritime claims")]

  * [Continental shelf](/wiki/Continental_shelf "Continental shelf"): 200 m (660 ft) depth or to the depth of exploitation
  * [Exclusive economic zone](/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone "Exclusive economic zone"): 200 [nmi](/wiki/Nautical_mile "Nautical mile") (370.4 km; 230.2 mi). The exact EEZ is due to conventions with neighbouring states.
  * Territorial sea: 12 nmi (22.2 km; 13.8 mi)

## Physical
Geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_Germany&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Physical Geography")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Deutschland_topo.jpg/170px-
Deutschland_topo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Deutschland_topo.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Deutschland_topo.jpg "Enlarge")

Topographic map of Germany

The northern third of the country lies in the [North European
Plain](/wiki/North_European_Plain "North European Plain"), with flat terrain
crossed by northward-flowing watercourses ([Elbe](/wiki/Elbe "Elbe"),
[Ems](/wiki/Ems_\(river\) "Ems \(river\)"), [Weser](/wiki/Weser "Weser"),
[Oder](/wiki/Oder "Oder")). [Wetlands](/wiki/Wetlands "Wetlands") and marshy
conditions are found close to the Dutch border and along the
[Frisian](/wiki/Frisia "Frisia") coast. Sandy [Mecklenburg](/wiki/Mecklenburg
"Mecklenburg") in the northeast has many glacier-formed
[lakes](/wiki/Mecklenburg_Lake_District "Mecklenburg Lake District") dating to
the [last glacial period](/wiki/Last_glacial_period "Last glacial period").

Moving south, central Germany features rough and somewhat patternless hilly
and mountainous countryside, some of it formed by ancient
[volcanic](/wiki/Volcano "Volcano") activity. The [Rhine](/wiki/Rhine "Rhine")
valley cuts through the western part of this region. The central uplands
continue east and north as far as the [Saale](/wiki/Saale "Saale") and merge
with the [Ore Mountains](/wiki/Ore_Mountains_\(Germany\) "Ore Mountains
\(Germany\)") on the border with the [Czech Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic
"Czech Republic"). Upland regions include the [Eifel](/wiki/Eifel "Eifel"),
[Hunsrück](/wiki/Hunsr%C3%BCck "Hunsrück") and [Palatine
Forest](/wiki/Palatine_Forest "Palatine Forest") west of the Rhine, the
[Taunus](/wiki/Taunus "Taunus") hills north of [Frankfurt](/wiki/Frankfurt
"Frankfurt"), the [Vogelsberg](/wiki/Vogelsberg "Vogelsberg") massif, the
[Rhön](/wiki/Rh%C3%B6n "Rhön"), and the [Thüringer
Wald](/wiki/Th%C3%BCringer_Wald "Thüringer Wald"). South of
[Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin"), the east-central part of the country is more
like the low northern areas, with sandy soil and river wetlands such as the
[Spreewald](/wiki/Spreewald "Spreewald") region.

Southern Germany's landforms are defined by various linear hill and mountain
ranges like the two adjacent ranges of the [Swabian](/wiki/Swabian_Alb
"Swabian Alb") and [Franconian Alb](/wiki/Franconian_Alb "Franconian Alb")
(reaching approximately from the source of the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube")
in the southwest of [Baden-Württemberg](/wiki/Baden-W%C3%BCrttemberg "Baden-
Württemberg"), south of [Stuttgart](/wiki/Stuttgart "Stuttgart"), across
[Swabia](/wiki/Swabia "Swabia") into [Central
Franconia](/wiki/Central_Franconia "Central Franconia") and to the valley of
the river [Main](/wiki/Main_\(river\) "Main \(river\)")) and the [Bavarian
Forest](/wiki/Bavarian_Forest "Bavarian Forest") along the border between
Bavaria and the Czech Republic. The [Alps](/wiki/Alps "Alps") on the southern
border are the highest mountains, but relatively little Alpine terrain lies
within Germany (in southeastern Swabia and [Upper Bavaria](/wiki/Upper_Bavaria
"Upper Bavaria")) compared to Switzerland and Austria. The [Black
Forest](/wiki/Black_Forest "Black Forest"), on the southwestern border with
France, separates the Rhine from the headwaters of the [Danube](/wiki/Danube
"Danube") on its eastern slopes.

###
Climate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_Germany&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Climate")]

[![Coastal
dunes](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Sylt_Rotes_Kliff.jpg/175px-
Sylt_Rotes_Kliff.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sylt_Rotes_Kliff.jpg)

Summer coastal climate on the island of [Sylt](/wiki/Sylt "Sylt") in
[Schleswig-Holstein](/wiki/Schleswig-Holstein "Schleswig-Holstein")

[![Thuringian
Forest](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Th%C3%BCringerwald.JPG/209px-
Th%C3%BCringerwald.JPG)](/wiki/File:Th%C3%BCringerwald.JPG)

[Thuringian Forests](/wiki/Thuringian_Forest "Thuringian Forest") in winter

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Germany_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/300px-
Germany_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Germany_K%C3%B6ppen.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Germany_K%C3%B6ppen.svg "Enlarge")

[Köppen climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification
"Köppen climate classification") types of Germany

The North-South difference in Germany, between N 55:03 (at
[List](/wiki/List,_Germany "List, Germany") on [Sylt](/wiki/Sylt "Sylt")) and
N 47:16 (around [Oberstdorf](/wiki/Oberstdorf "Oberstdorf"),
[Bavaria](/wiki/Bavaria "Bavaria")) equals almost eight
[Latitudes](/wiki/Latitudes "Latitudes") (or 889 km), but this can't largely
be seen in different average temperatures. There is sooner a stronger West-
East temperature factor instead. This is explained by the North's flat and
open landscapes and its closeness to the sea, and South's higher terrain,
larger distance from the sea, and the [Alps](/wiki/Alps "Alps"). These
mountains prevents much of the usually warmer
[Mediterranean](/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea "Mediterranean Sea") air to blow up
into southern Germany. And north of the Alps and the
[Carpathians](/wiki/Carpathians "Carpathians"), the farther away from the
[Atlantic Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean") with for its Latitudes
warm current, known as the [Gulfstream](/wiki/Gulf_Stream "Gulf Stream") \-
and the closer to [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia")'s and
[Siberia](/wiki/Siberia "Siberia")'s extremely cold winter winds, one gets,
the local climate becomes colder, even at the same Latitude and altitude. Even
if Siberian winter winds are not dominating, when they do hit Germany,
temperatures can in extreme cases fall to -30 C and below during the nights,
and this has an effect on the average temperatures of November to March.
Although rare, when such cold air reaches Germany, the Eastern parts becomes
more affected compared to the Western parts. These factors results in, that
[Hamburg](/wiki/Hamburg "Hamburg") in the North has the same annual average
temperature as [Munich](/wiki/Munich "Munich") in the South has. The annual
average temperature in Hamburg is +9.5 C and +9.7 in Munich [3] Whilst
[Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin") has an annual average temperature +9,9 C [4]

The warmest area in Germany is the area bordering to [France](/wiki/France
"France") and west of the [Schwartzwald](/wiki/Schwartzwald "Schwartzwald")
hills. Roughly between [Karlsruhe](/wiki/Karlsruhe "Karlsruhe") in the north,
and down to the [Swiss](/wiki/Switzerland "Switzerland") border. Whilst the
coldest area (except for mountain peaks) is found in the southeastern parts of
eastern Germany, around [Dresden](/wiki/Dresden "Dresden") and
[Görlitz](/wiki/G%C3%B6rlitz "Görlitz"); roughly just two Latitudes higher.
But the difference at annual average base, isn't extreme. [Freiburg im
Breisgau](/wiki/Freiburg_im_Breisgau "Freiburg im Breisgau") (located a little
south of Karlsruhe) has an averare annual temperature of +11.4 C,
[Görlitz](/wiki/G%C3%B6rlitz "Görlitz") has an equal value of +8.8 C. A
difference of 2.6 degree C. [5] Colder meteorological stations in Germany can
be found, but mainly at notably higher altitudes.

Germany's [climate](/wiki/Climate "Climate") is [temperate](/wiki/Temperate
"Temperate") and [marine](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate"), with cold,
cloudy, wet winters and moderate warm summers and in the south occasional warm
[föhn wind](/wiki/F%C3%B6hn_wind "Föhn wind"). The greater part of Germany
lies in the cool/temperate climatic zone in which humid westerly winds
predominate. In the northwest and the north, the climate is oceanic and rain
falls all the year round. Winters there are relatively mild and summers
comparatively cool. In the east, the climate shows clear continental features;
winters can be very cold for long periods, and summers can become very warm.
Dry periods are often recorded.

In the centre and the south, there is a transitional climate which may be
predominantly oceanic or continental, according to the general weather
situation. Winters are mild and summers tend to be cool, though maximum
temperatures can exceed 30 [°C](/wiki/Celsius "Celsius") (86
[°F](/wiki/Fahrenheit "Fahrenheit")) for several days in a row during heat
waves. The warmest regions of Germany can be found in the south-west (see
[rhine rift](/wiki/Rhine_rift "Rhine rift"), [German Wine
Route](/wiki/German_Wine_Route "German Wine Route") and
[Palatinate](/wiki/Palatinate_\(region\) "Palatinate \(region\)")). Here
summers can be hot with many days exceeding 30 [°C](/wiki/Celsius "Celsius")
(86 [°F](/wiki/Fahrenheit "Fahrenheit")). Sometimes, minimum temperatures do
not drop below 20 [°C](/wiki/Celsius "Celsius") (68 [°F](/wiki/Fahrenheit
"Fahrenheit")), which is relatively rare in other regions.[6][7]

### Land
use[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_Germany&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Land use")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Hintersee.jpg/220px-
Hintersee.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hintersee.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hintersee.jpg "Enlarge")

[Alpine](/wiki/Alps "Alps") scenery in [Bavaria](/wiki/Bavaria "Bavaria")

Germany covers a total of 357,021 km2 (137,847 sq mi), of which 5,157 km2
(1,991 sq mi) is [irrigated land](/wiki/Irrigated_land "Irrigated land") and
8,350 km2 (3,220 sq mi) is covered by water, the largest lakes being [Lake
Constance](/wiki/Lake_Constance "Lake Constance") (total area of 536 km2 (207
sq mi), with 62% of the shore being German; international
[borders](/wiki/Border "Border") are not defined on the lake itself),
[Müritz](/wiki/M%C3%BCritz "Müritz") (117 km2 or 45 sq mi) and
[Chiemsee](/wiki/Chiemsee "Chiemsee") (80 km2 or 31 sq mi). The majority of
Germany is covered by either [arable land](/wiki/Arable_land "Arable land")
(33.95%); permanent crops cover 0.57% of the land.

Germany has a total of 2,389 km (1,484 mi) of coastline, and borders totaling
3,714 km (2,308 mi) (clockwise from north: [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark")
140 km (87 mi), [Poland](/wiki/Poland "Poland") 467 km (290 mi), [Czech
Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic "Czech Republic") 704 km (437 mi),[8]
[Austria](/wiki/Austria "Austria") 801 km (498 mi),
[Switzerland](/wiki/Switzerland "Switzerland") 348 km (216 mi),
[France](/wiki/France "France") 418 km (260 mi), [Luxembourg](/wiki/Luxembourg
"Luxembourg") 128 km (80 mi), [Belgium](/wiki/Belgium "Belgium") 133 km (83
mi), [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands") 575 km (357 mi)). The
German-Austrian border crosses itself near [Jungholz](/wiki/Jungholz
"Jungholz"). The border with Belgium includes 5 German exclaves because the
[Vennbahn](/wiki/Vennbahn "Vennbahn") railway is on Belgian territory crossing
in and out of Germany.

###
Rivers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_Germany&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Rivers")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Germanymap2.png/170px-
Germanymap2.png)](/wiki/File:Germanymap2.png)

[](/wiki/File:Germanymap2.png "Enlarge")

The major German rivers

For a more comprehensive list, see [List of rivers of
Germany](/wiki/List_of_rivers_of_Germany "List of rivers of Germany").

The main rivers in Germany are:

  * the [Rhine](/wiki/Rhine "Rhine") (_Rhein_ in [German](/wiki/German_language "German language")) with a German section extending 865 km (537 mi) (main tributaries including the [Neckar](/wiki/Neckar "Neckar"), the [Main](/wiki/Main_\(river\) "Main \(river\)") and the [Moselle](/wiki/Moselle_River "Moselle River") (_Mosel_));
  * the [Elbe](/wiki/Elbe "Elbe") with a German section of 727 km (452 mi) (also drains into the [North Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North Sea")); and
  * the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") (_Donau_) with a German length of 687 km (427 mi).

Further important rivers include the [Saale](/wiki/Saale "Saale") and the Main
in central Germany, the Neckar in the southwest, the [Weser](/wiki/Weser
"Weser") in the North and the Oder at the eastern border.

  * [Iron ore](/wiki/Iron_ore "Iron ore"), [coal](/wiki/Coal "Coal"), [potash](/wiki/Potash "Potash"), [timber](/wiki/Timber "Timber"), [lignite](/wiki/Lignite "Lignite"), [uranium](/wiki/Uranium "Uranium"), [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper"), [petroleum](/wiki/Petroleum "Petroleum"), [natural gas](/wiki/Natural_gas "Natural gas"), [salt](/wiki/Salt "Salt"), [nickel](/wiki/Nickel "Nickel"), and [water](/wiki/Water "Water").

##
Environment[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_Germany&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Environment")]

[![Lüneburg
Heath](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/HeideblueteTiefental.JPG/178px-
HeideblueteTiefental.JPG)](/wiki/File:HeideblueteTiefental.JPG)

The [Lüneburg Heath Nature Reserve](/wiki/L%C3%BCneburg_Heath_Nature_Reserve
"Lüneburg Heath Nature Reserve") in [Lower Saxony](/wiki/Lower_Saxony "Lower
Saxony")

[![Eagle](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Aquila_chrysaetos_Flickr.jpg/200px-
Aquila_chrysaetos_Flickr.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aquila_chrysaetos_Flickr.jpg)

The [eagle](/wiki/Golden_eagle "Golden eagle") is a protected bird of prey

Current issues

  * Emissions from coal-burning utilities and industries contribute to air pollution; acid rain, resulting from sulphur dioxide emissions, is damaging [forests](/wiki/Forest "Forest"); pollution in the Baltic Sea from raw sewage and industrial effluents from rivers in eastern Germany; [hazardous waste](/wiki/Hazardous_waste "Hazardous waste") disposal; government (under Chancellor Schröder, SPD) announced intent to end the use of nuclear power for producing electricity; government working to meet EU commitment to identify nature preservation areas in line with the EU's Flora, Fauna, and Habitat directive. Germany's last glacier is disappearing.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

International agreements

  * Party to: Air Pollution, Air Pollution-[Nitrogen oxides](/wiki/Nitrogen_oxides "Nitrogen oxides"), Air Pollution-Persistent Organic Pollutants, Air Pollution-Sulphur 85, Air Pollution-Sulphur 94, Air Pollution-Volatile Organic Compounds, Antarctic-Environmental Protocol, [Antarctic Treaty](/wiki/Antarctic_Treaty "Antarctic Treaty"), [Biodiversity](/wiki/Biodiversity "Biodiversity"), [Climate Change](/wiki/Climate_Change "Climate Change"), Climate Change-[Kyoto Protocol](/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol "Kyoto Protocol"), [Desertification](/wiki/Desertification "Desertification"), Endangered Species, [Environmental Modification](/wiki/Environmental_Modification "Environmental Modification"), Hazardous Wastes, [Law of the Sea](/wiki/Law_of_the_Sea "Law of the Sea"), Marine Dumping, Nuclear Test Ban, Ozone Layer Protection, Ship Pollution, [Tropical Timber 83](/wiki/Tropical_Timber_83 "Tropical Timber 83"), [Tropical Timber 94](/wiki/Tropical_Timber_94 "Tropical Timber 94"), Wetlands, Whaling
  * Signed, but not ratified: none

Natural hazards

  * Flooding through rivers after heavy rainfall, such as during the [2002 European floods](/wiki/2002_European_floods "2002 European floods"), or [Storm surge](/wiki/Storm_surge "Storm surge"), such as the [North Sea flood of 1962](/wiki/North_Sea_flood_of_1962 "North Sea flood of 1962") and the historic floods of [1362](/wiki/Grote_Mandrenke "Grote Mandrenke") and [1634](/wiki/Burchardi_flood "Burchardi flood") that changed the coastline of what is now the west coast of [Schleswig-Holstein](/wiki/Schleswig-Holstein "Schleswig-Holstein").

### Flora and
Fauna[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_Germany&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Flora and Fauna")]

[![Red
Deer](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Cervus_elaphus_11.jpg/199px-
Cervus_elaphus_11.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cervus_elaphus_11.jpg)

[Deer](/wiki/Red_Deer "Red Deer") are widespread species

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Seehunde_auf_Duene.jpg/200px-
Seehunde_auf_Duene.jpg)](/wiki/File:Seehunde_auf_Duene.jpg)

[Phytogeographically](/wiki/Phytogeography "Phytogeography"), Germany is
shared between the Atlantic European and Central European provinces of the
[Circumboreal Region](/wiki/Circumboreal_Region "Circumboreal Region") within
the [Boreal Kingdom](/wiki/Boreal_Kingdom "Boreal Kingdom"). The territory of
Germany can be subdivided into two [ecoregions](/wiki/Ecoregion "Ecoregion"):
European-Mediterranean montane mixed forests and Northeast-Atlantic shelf
marine.[9] The majority of Germany is covered by either [arable
land](/wiki/Arable_land "Arable land") (33%) or [forestry](/wiki/Forestry
"Forestry") and [woodland](/wiki/Woodland "Woodland") (31%). Only 15% is
covered by permanent pastures.

Plants and animals are those generally common to middle Europe. Beeches, oaks,
and other deciduous trees constitute one-third of the forests; conifers are
increasing as a result of reforestation. Spruce and fir trees predominate in
the upper mountains, while pine and larch are found in sandy soil. There are
many species of ferns, flowers, fungi, and mosses. Fish abound in the rivers
and the North Sea. Wild animals include deer, wild boar, mouflon, fox, badger,
hare, and small numbers of beaver. Various migratory birds cross Germany in
the spring and autumn.

The [national parks in Germany](/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Germany "List
of national parks of Germany") include the [Wadden Sea National
Parks](/wiki/Wadden_Sea_National_Parks "Wadden Sea National Parks"), the
[Jasmund National Park](/wiki/Jasmund_National_Park "Jasmund National Park"),
the [Vorpommern Lagoon Area National
Park](/wiki/Vorpommern_Lagoon_Area_National_Park "Vorpommern Lagoon Area
National Park"), the [Müritz National Park](/wiki/M%C3%BCritz_National_Park
"Müritz National Park"), the [Lower Oder Valley National
Park](/wiki/Lower_Oder_Valley_National_Park "Lower Oder Valley National
Park"), the [Harz National Park](/wiki/Harz_National_Park "Harz National
Park"), the [Saxon Switzerland National
Park](/wiki/Saxon_Switzerland_National_Park "Saxon Switzerland National Park")
and the [Bavarian Forest National Park](/wiki/Bavarian_Forest_National_Park
"Bavarian Forest National Park").

Germany is known for its many [zoological gardens](/wiki/Zoological_garden
"Zoological garden"), wildlife parks, aquaria, and bird parks.[10] More than
400 registered zoos and animal parks operate in Germany, which is believed to
be the largest number in any single country of the world.[11] The
[Zoologischer Garten Berlin](/wiki/Berlin_Zoological_Garden "Berlin Zoological
Garden") is the oldest zoo in Germany and presents the most comprehensive
collection of species in the world.[12]

###
Demographics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_Germany&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Demographics")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Pop_density_of_Germany.png/170px-
Pop_density_of_Germany.png)](/wiki/File:Pop_density_of_Germany.png)

[](/wiki/File:Pop_density_of_Germany.png "Enlarge")

Population density

Main article: [Demographics of Germany](/wiki/Demographics_of_Germany
"Demographics of Germany")

With an estimated 81.8 million inhabitants in January 2010, Germany is the
most populous country in the European Union and ranks as the [15th largest
country](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population "List of countries by
population") in the world in terms of population. Its [population
density](/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_population_density
"List of sovereign states and dependent territories by population density")
stands at 229.4 inhabitants per square kilometre (594/sq mi). The [United
Nations Population Fund](/wiki/United_Nations_Population_Fund "United Nations
Population Fund") lists Germany as host to the [third-highest number of
international migrants
worldwide](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_immigrant_population "List of countries
by immigrant population"),[13] around 20% of Germany´s population do not hold
a German passport or are descendants of immigrants.

### Administrative
divisions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_Germany&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Administrative divisions")]

Germany comprises [sixteen states](/wiki/States_of_Germany "States of
Germany") that are collectively referred to as _Länder_.[14] Each state has
its own state constitution[15] and is largely autonomous in regard to its
internal organisation. Due to differences in size and population the
[subdivision of these states](/wiki/States_of_Germany#Further_subdivisions
"States of Germany") varies, especially between [city
states](/wiki/City_states "City states") (_Stadtstaaten_) and states with
larger territories (_Flächenländer_). For regional administrative purposes
five states, namely Baden-Württemberg, Bavaria, Hesse, North Rhine-Westphalia
and Saxony, consist of a total of 22 [Government
Districts](/wiki/Regierungsbezirke "Regierungsbezirke") (_Regierungsbezirke_).
As of 2009 Germany is divided into 403 [districts](/wiki/Districts_of_Germany
"Districts of Germany") (_Kreise_) on municipal level, these consist of 301
[rural districts](/wiki/List_of_rural_districts_of_Germany "List of rural
districts of Germany") and 102 [urban
districts](/wiki/Urban_districts_of_Germany "Urban districts of Germany").[16]

Germany has a number of large cities; the most populous are:

[Dortmund](/wiki/Dortmund "Dortmund"), [Duisburg](/wiki/Duisburg "Duisburg"),
and [Bochum](/wiki/Bochum "Bochum").
